From Span. 'llano'. To flatten something is šḳatš.
To become thin is ḳooš; sḳosa. Also lxawa.

A measure between the first and second fingers is čelḳe. A measure from the thumb to the second, third, or fourth finger is čʰiya. A measure with the arms wide open is ḳʰata; ḳʰat-š.
The latter is 'of the east'. Also tuwančuk.
The latter is 'of the east'. Also tuwančuk.
To do something clumsily, with the left hand is šḳaranta.
Means around the edge. Also Span. [latu].
To break/separate with the hand is č̣ˀaxl-š.
maxk- and yaaš, mean 'to put inside'. 'To put up' is uut-š.
To put up or on top of is tewš.
To put up or on top of is tewš.
To put inside is maxk-š. Also ḳʰuyla; ḳʰuyltan. Suffix form is -kiš.
To take down, let down is čʰixunš.
The latter means to share inheritance.
The latter means to share inheritance.
ḳah means 'to ask for on credit'.
ḳah means 'to ask for on credit'.
From Span. 'pobre' man. Verbal form is tomaŋ.
To give with the hand is čʰals. To give a gift is onan-.
Possessive suffix. Verbal form does not usually occur; idea is expressed 'There is ...of me.'
Means 'to push', as in excrete 04.660, or give birth 04.720.
To guide the animals from corral to pasture. To bring them back from pasture is axkškiš.
Means to carry with both hands, like a box.
Also tʰušša; čʰič. To load up is xep-š.
Respectively: leave; start out on a trip.
Respectively: leave; start out on a trip.
The latter is to run at full speed. Uru-J form is šat-. Also šaxt-š.
The latter is to run at full speed. Uru-J form is šat-. Also šaxt-š.
Also means 'go' 10.470. Uru-J form is oḳčˀin.
To throw outside (to 'kick out') is čʰatḳatš.
Respectively: refers to person falling down; cause to fall (people). To fall over is ḳʰatš.
Respectively: refers to person falling down; cause to fall (people). To fall over is ḳʰatš.
Means 'bent, twisted'. To twist/turn the body when walking is kexrš.
Also tʰelx-š; tʰers. To wrap up with rope is xʷeran-š.
A small open-weave b. Also pac̷, means 'to make a b. (low, flat)', tightly woven of straw and pig thong.
To wash things (not clothes) is axunš.
Also means to clean the nose.
Also wičanš, to pour out, scatter (solids).
Means 'to drag'. kaxl- means 'to pull out'.
Means torn, worn out (such as clothes).
Respectively: break or tear (rope, etc.); break or snap something like wood or iron.
Respectively: break or tear (rope, etc.); break or snap something like wood or iron.
To cut with a hard instrument (two hard pieces), such as teeth, pliers, or rocks, is kˀutš. To cut off is murš.
To cut with a hard instrument (two hard pieces), such as teeth, pliers, or rocks, is kˀutš. To cut off is murš.
Respectively: throw and hit with something like a stone; hit with hand or stick.
Respectively: throw and hit with something like a stone; hit with hand or stick.

Uru-J form is ḳoxč. Also kˀaya, a tightly braided rope. A rope used for measuring is eḳa. Rope made of straw is ḳaru. Rope with four 'caitos' is molukˀu. R. with five 'caitos' is šḳata. R. with eight 'caitos' is tika; tikḳoč. A 'caito' is a braided rope of yarn.
Respectively: as in untie belt of clothes; to come untied.
Respectively: as in untie belt of clothes; to come untied.
The latter means to tie up animals, people.
The latter means to tie up animals, people.
The latter is a small edible tuberous root. A thick root is pira.
The latter is a small edible tuberous root. A thick root is pira.
Uru-J form is pʰiti, means 'straw, roof' 07.510.
Respectively: dig a hole; to dig and move dirt with a shovel.
Respectively: dig a hole; to dig and move dirt with a shovel.
Refers to a dibble stick, which does the work of a plow. Uru-J form is tuɲi. Cf. 'pole' 07.560.
Respectively: from Span. 'adobe'; mud for plastering walls.
Respectively: from Span. 'adobe'; mud for plastering walls.
Refers to the 'tola' for the roof. Cf. Quechua 'hut' 07.130. also pʰit, 'straw'.
Refers to straw roof. Uru-J form is pʰiti, means 'straw, roof'.
Respectively: 'spread out-skin'; a thick, woven blanket or mat to sleep on top of or underneath.
Respectively: 'spread out-skin'; a thick, woven blanket or mat to sleep on top of or underneath.
The latter is 'doorway'. Uru-J forms are čaxʷkš and šana.
The latter is 'doorway'. Uru-J forms are čaxʷkš and šana.
A house not in use is ḳatsa. Uru-J form is ḳʰuya. Uru-I form is ḳoya.
Also škurš, braiding rope; škuru is noun form.
The former is a comb made of roots. Verbal form is č̣ʰixk-š.
The former is a comb made of roots. Verbal form is č̣ʰixk-š.
For the hair. An o. of bronze for the hair is lawraḳi. An adornment for the neck of a llama is ḳx̣ac̷, which is actually the word for a man's purse, that he wears in front.
The latter means 'to fasten with a pin'.
The latter means 'to fasten with a pin'.
Refers to sandals. To put on sandals is č̣ʰat-š.
The outer cloth, flung over and around as a wrap.
pari is a loosely twisted thread/yarn. čiki, 'string', like a shoestring. A really strong thread or wire is ḳʷayra, (perhaps Aymara?), also can refer to a strong person.
Also ḳʰaxtʰat-š, means to weave tightly.
Respectively: twirl the spindle; spin thread
Respectively: twirl the spindle; spin thread
Raw wool is kˀana; ḳalʸači. Raw alpaca w. is sax̣sali.

The latter is to dress another.
An egg that is not fresh is xinšxinta.
Also čˀuwanš, to milk for another person.
'Rock salt' is ḳulo/ḳulu. Uru-J form is yiku.
Uru-J form is kʰewa. A 'fat' animal is x̣ata.
Refers to a broth (thin). Also pˀišḳe, a quinoa soup.
Meat from wild animals is šalʸkˀa a specialized term, perhaps from Aymara (?).
The latter is a grinding stone, used on flat surface.
The latter is a grinding stone, used on flat surface.
The former is to g. with a round stone.
The former is to g. with a round stone.
Flour that is not ground well is čʰama.
The latter refers to large, clay 'cántaro'. A large jar to hold urine for fermenting is putiša. This is used to wash the hair.

Also ḳis, means to stir while cooking.
Also ḳis, means to stir while cooking.

Means 'to chew' for making 'chicha' (a corn drink).
uwa is a particular food. Uru-J form is luli.
To eat with the hands is č̣ʰawk-š.
To eat with the hands is č̣ʰawk-š.
Also čoɲa, sickly, without energy; ox̣ša, lazy, worthless.
Former is verbal form. Also čˀawa, a hard swelling or lump.
Former is verbal form. Also čˀawa, a hard swelling or lump.
The former refers to wounding. Also šḳira, 'sarna'.
The former refers to wounding. Also šḳira, 'sarna'.
Also č̣ˀuxlɲi, a high fever. To make sick is laa kʰiš. 'To become sick (in a special context)' is ašinš.
Also č̣ˀuxlɲi, a high fever. To make sick is laa kʰiš. 'To become sick (in a special context)' is ašinš.

Respectively: a person's strength; a strong object, such as a pole.
Respectively: a person's strength; a strong object, such as a pole.
A corpse or cadaver in the field, usually of animals.

Means to be the father of, stative, verbalized noun.

To sleep well is tx̣ax̣i-maačiṣ̌; tx̣ax̣i-matš. Uru-J form is txax-.
Respectively: bite with front teeth (to cut); bite of an animal. Uru-J form is tʰup-.
Respectively: bite with front teeth (to cut); bite of an animal. Uru-J form is tʰup-.
Respectively: verbal form; noun form; means 'to cause to salivate', perhaps Aymara or Quechua. To spit out something solid is latš.

Respectively: verbal form; noun form; means 'to cause to salivate', perhaps Aymara or Quechua. To spit out something solid is latš.
Noun form is pʰalɲi; pʰalʸɲi. The latter has the meaning of 'bursts', as in 'burst out in sweat'.

Verbal form is xex-š, also means 'rest' 04.912.

Uru-J form is tusi. Uru-I form is tuši.
Uru-J form is tusi. Uru-I form is tuši.
'Knee cap' is šmatʰi. Uru-J form is oo.
Also ḳx̣ar is-ɲi. Uru-J form is is-ni.
Includes the arm up to the elbow. 'Fist' is moḳ-o. Uru-J form is ḳxara. Uru-I form is ḳʰara.
Also means 'voice' 18.110. Uru-J form is xora.
Uru-J form is iṣ̌ḳe. Front teeth are samitʰupš.
A thick lip is puti; šmeklu. Uru-J form is atpulu.
Small mouth is spora. Uru-J form is ata.
Also ḳʰiri, also means 'turned up'. Uru-J form is oša.
Pupil of the eye is mamanilʸa. 'Cross-eyed' is č̣ʰuxk ḳaru; ḳˀiṣ̌u. Uru-J form is c̷ʰuxki. Uru-I form is c̷suki.
Uru-J form is ača; Uru-I form is či.
'Tailbone, end of spine' is šḳutu. Uru-J form is kʰursi.
Small cow's horn, used as a musical instrument during Carnival. Also totʰi.
Also means 'red' 15.660. Uru-J form is lxok.
'Toad' is škara. A black toad is akulʸa. šḳoḳa is 'tadpole'.
Refers to a black spider. A white spider is wayu.
Refers to specific kinds of hawks. Also paka. Uru-J form is ṣ̌ḳara.
Refers to specific kinds of hawks. Also paka. Uru-J form is ṣ̌ḳara.
The former refers to a medium-sized specific kind. The latter refers to 'kuchi', a black pig. Also other terms for specific colors.
The former refers to a medium-sized specific kind. The latter refers to 'kuchi', a black pig. Also other terms for specific colors.
Possibly from Span. 'oveja'. A two-year-old s. is xura.
The former is verb, means 'to take to pasture'. Also sakʷa, a specific kind of grass.
The former is verb, means 'to take to pasture'. Also sakʷa, a specific kind of grass.

Note metathesis. Suffix -ki is a focus particle. 'My' is wext.
Also atči. Uru-J form is expi.
Also atči. Uru-J form is expi.
xilwič refers to 'brothers of a girl'.
A carnal child is apʰa-runa; runa is 'person' in Quechua.
Uru-J form is apayšu. Uru-I form is epḳʰaski.
Cf. 'husband' 02.310 and 'boy' 02.250. Uru-J form is lukwawa. Uru-I form is luxa.

ḳʰan-č̣a means 'he illuminates'. Uru-J form is pexk-.

The former is 'to light a fire'. Also peḳ-š; ux peḳ.
The former is 'to light a fire'. Also peḳ-š; ux peḳ.
Also means 'dust' 01.213. Uru-J form is ṣ̌ḳeti.
Verbal form is čix-š. Uru-J form is čixɲi.
A northeast wind is xarḳawi; xarḳʰawi. A west wind is tʰami. The god of the wind is šoḳo. Uru-J form is tʰami.
A large cloud is aḳʰikila. 'Cloudy' is kopxa; koxpkiš.
Also means 'month'14.710. Uru-J form is xiiš.
Also means 'day' 14.410. 'Sunshine' is siis. Uru-J form is tʰuɲi.
Respectively: sedimentary rock, a flat, long rock; metamorphic rock. A hard rock, black or grey is ayi. A stone for the 'bola' is miči. Uru-J form is maši.
Respectively: sedimentary rock, a flat, long rock; metamorphic rock. A hard rock, black or grey is ayi. A stone for the 'bola' is miči. Uru-J form is maši.
Refers to a small stick used for weaving or measuring.
A river with a high bank is kora. Branch of river is lax̣ma.
Bubbles on water (from grease, etc.) is smoy-smoy-ɲi.
Uru-J form is ḳʰaši. Uru-I form is ḳoši.
Also čˀutu, a large or small mound; pata means 'small hill'.
alʸpi means 'muddy water'. Black moist mud is čaymari.
A piece of land is čiya, in the sense of a designated plot, apportioned out to a head of household for planting quinua for the year. Uru-J form is yoḳa.
Also means 'afternoon'. Verbal form is šeštan.
Also means 'moon' 01.530. Uru-J form is xiiš.
sḳoo means 'white salty residue on the ground'. 'Salty water' is atooḳara; čˀukxa.
Also means 'voice' 18.110. 'To make noise' is aran-.
Means without a point or edge.
ḳut- means 'to heat'. To be hot from the sun is laxkš; sii.
To heat up is tx̣utxun-š; tx̣utun-š. ḳut- means 'to heat'.
The latter means to feel the cold.
The latter means to feel the cold.
Results from a fox crossing the path.
The latter means 'to hurt'. Also miš.
The latter means 'to hurt'. Also miš.
Refers to 'dry tears', as seen on the figures in the church.
The latter is noun form 'shameful things'.
The latter is noun form 'shameful things'.
The latter also means to have intercourse, 04.670.
The latter also means to have intercourse, 04.670.
Verbal form is luxps, not common.
Verbal form is luxps, not common.
The former is to recognize a person.
The former is to recognize a person.
From Span. 'loco'. Also šaxraṣ̌ tanta, 'evil spirit grabbed'.
Means 'one who studies'. Also tʰaaxinta ṣ̌oɲi 'taught person'.
Means 'not known'. Also čʰoxšakuɲ, 'secretly'; čʰox, 'hide away'.
Also anakʰey 'No! Leave it!'; ana čʰul 'nothing of'; anami 'perhaps not'; ana xaḳšilta 'no one'.
A special kind of singing with words is rim-š.
Means 'to ask for on credit'. max-š means 'to ask (various times)'. Also may-š.
Means 'to ask for on credit'. max-š means 'to ask (various times)'. Also may-š.
Refers to flamingo hunting, 'to go to hit' flamingo.
Means 'to hit, throw the bola (wild game when hunting)'.
Means 'justice do', from Span. 'justicia'. Also [xusxita]ṣ̌ kʰee-, be judged.
From Span. 'testigo'. Also [kintra] čiiɲi], lit. 'against speakers'.
Means to give honor, from Span. 'honor; honra'.
